content:
The star means that the message was sent from a person whose address is in your addressbook. To remove it, you need 1) a folder named chrome in your profile, 2) a text file named userChrome.css in the folder, and 3) this content in that file: 

.emailStar {     display: none !important; }
creator: davidsk

content: I suggest reviewing your setup on Thunderbird and then applying that to the phone's email app. This is not a Thunderbird issue, but an iphone email app issue.
creator: davidsk

content:
If the account is set up as POP on TB with default settings, messages are downloaded to the computer and deleted from the mail server, so they are not available to be read on the phone. If the account is POP, change it to IMAP:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Convert_a_POP_account_to_a_IMAP_account

The account is probably already IMAP on the phone, as that is the usual default for mobile devices. You can easily check as the incoming POP server is pop.shaw.ca and the incoming IMAP is imap.shaw.ca.

https://support.shaw.ca/t5/internet-articles/about-pop-and-imap-email-server-settings/ta-p/6731
creator: sfhowes

content:
Hello there We have read the question We try to help


Your connections to your server that you are obviously using for your Thunderbird email business will be from Thunderbird itself. Your settings for this are a firewall or your antivirus program and whether VPN settings themselves for this connection or with your SMTP configuration for outgoing internet traffic will not be as they should be today. Please look up the disruptive topic for a moment. Configure yourself what it would be? If you think you have a disturbing add-on or extension, you can boot into trouble shoot mode for Thunderbird. If not, it could be other software. Check whether you can do this with the add-ons disabled and find the disturbing piece of software add-on in this way and delete it.


Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there


https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

VPN services bypass your and some settings directly to reach their destinations. Your pre-existing configuration is bypassed by directly using your VPN software.

Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:

content: First, the unified view is just that, a view. The actual Gmail inbox is what is being acted up. For the phone to be in sync, both need to be set up as IMAP accounts. If unsure, highlight account name on main view, rightclick and select settings, then click 'server settings' and the type (IMAP or POP) will be displayed. Also, you cannot change an account from one to the other, but must set up a new account.

content:
La Modalità risoluzione dei problemi fa essenzialmente due cose (https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/modalita-risoluzione-problemi-thunderbird#w_che-cosa-viene-disattivato-in-modalita-risoluzione-problemi):

  1. Disattiva tutte le estensioni
  2. Disabilita l'accelerazione hardware

Se non hai estensioni, allora prova a disabilitare l'accelerazione hardware -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/impostazioni-thunderbird-pannello-avanzate#w_impostazioni-avanzate

p.s. Non ho idea di chi tu abbia contattato, ma non esiste l'assistenza di Firefox (ne di Thunderbird). In un programma distribuito gratuitamente chi dovrebbe pagare i tecnici che fanno assistenza? Ovviamente se preferisci passare ad un altro programma, nessun ti trattiene.
creator: @next

content: Grazie per il supporto ed i consigli. Ho disattivato l'accelerazione hardware (l'ho trovata nell'editor della configurazione), ma non c'è stato nulla da fare, non è cambiato niente. Anzi ho notato altre anomalie (non dovute a quest'ultima operazione): oltre a non farmi vedere i nuovi messaggi, quando vado ad aprire i messaggi residenti in cartelle (vecchi, sono fermi al 6 maggio c.a.) alcuni non me li apre. In effetti ne ho moltissimi. Forse Thunderbird Portable ha delle limitazioni di quantità: quando salvo in zip tutta la cartella Thunderbird, il file .rar occupa alcuni giga, io l'ho configurato in modalità IMAP. Il problema me lo dà solo su uno dei quattro accounts configurati, quello di yahoo (in effetti è quello più utilizzato, contiene oltre 100 volte più messaggi degli altri tre messi insieme, senza contare i numerosi allegati). Non ho ancora verificato se su un altro PC, Thunderbird dà lo stesso problema, lo farò: ma quest'ultima installazione non è portable. Grazie comunque, Vincent p.s. Ne verrò fuori: passare ora come ora a un altro account necessiterebbe mesi e mesi, perlomeno per ricostruire l'alberatura delle numerosissime cartelle e trasferire tutti i messaggi

content: A livello di dimensioni Thunderbird ha come unica limitazione quella del filesystem (molti TB per ntfs). A livello pratico però è sconsigliato superare i 2/4 GB per singola cartella.

content:
ctrl+shift+F is (the original) Search Messages (Edit > Find) - searches an account's folders. Or potentially more, if you save it as a virtual folder / saved search.

ctrl+shift+K is quick filter - operates only on one folder

ctrl+K is global search - operates on all folders which have been enabled for indexing to Global Search (Settings > Indexing)

content: Gmail is it's own dance, but you do need to accept cookies (settings>privacy&security) and I always advise to NOT insert password, but wait until Google prompts for it. Once you respond to the Google prompt and click the 'allow' button, Google inserts a dedicated password for that PC to access Gmail - not transferable. That is, Google does not allow email clients to use the same password that you use for online access.

content: Try it with Windows running in safe mode, to ensure no effects from startup apps like Bitdefender (turning it 'off' is no guarantee of non-interference). You might also consider removing 2-factor authentication from the account, in case it's a factor (and not really necessary anyway).
creator: sfhowes

content:
I THINK I have RESOLVED the problem.

I was running PostgreSQL Server 16 x64 version

When I disabled this service on startup, Thunderbird would complete the authentication and allow email to start flowing.

Manually reenabling the service seemed to not prevent authentication.

I don't need PostgreSQL server running on startup so I will set this service to manually start.

Only other thing it could be would be the Adobe Genuine Software Monitoring Service that I disabled as well.
creator: krummenp

content:
Yes, running servers is known to interfere with OAuth authentication, e.g. see

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1373706?page=2

content: I always use a password, which gets entered automatically when I log in. I should point out that this failed login problem is intermittent and ongoing. Sometimes I can login, other times I have to wait several hours. But when the Thunderbird login fails, I can use Mail, and that app works fine.
creator: ronpike

content:
The point is, AT&T requires secure mail keys for desktop mail apps. The regular account password might work for webmail or phone mail apps, but not apps like TB (the Windows or OS X Mail clients are similar to mobile mail apps).

Remove the account's entries from Settings, Saved Passwords, restart TB, enter the secure mail key when asked for a password.

content:
you have gone to great lengths to cover whole provides your mail service, but if it is Microsoft via office or outlook.com for example, it may be they are refusing connections because your operating system is end of life.

Try right clicking a folder that is giving issues and selecting properties and then repair. It may be an indexing issue.

It could also be whatever is putting [!!SPAM]] on your message subjects is having difficulties.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The fact that forwarding it worked indicates that the mail folder just needs repair. Try highlighting the folder, right click, select properties and then click repair. That often works.
creator: davidsk

content:
I can't believe it, but you're right. It worked!

What happens to make a message require repair? Don't worry, if you don't know the answer, that's okay, I'm just agog...
creator: tcluster

content: First, I don't understand the underlying details, but for an overview, the message folder is two components: the message file and the index file (e.g., inbox, and inbox.msf). The msf file is the index and is continually rewritten as messages are added and deleted. On occasion, this gets corrupted, causing what you saw, but can also cause the sender of one message to appear as sender of a different message -- the message is still correct and processes correctly, but can appear incorrectly on message list pane. If you seek this, it's an indication of a needed repair. There, more than you wanted to know. :)
creator: davidsk

Hello there


Open the Thunderbird software. try to go to the account settings if this is possible. click on edit SMTP server. Please save your data by agreeing. And it's ready to use.
